messages.author: scherkus
messages.text: nit: blank lines between <system includes.h> and "regular chrome includes.h"

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text:
we really shouldn't require refcounting but let's save that for another day

there's some detangling of object lifetimes and cleanup of stream creation/deletion that has to happen first before we can tackling that beast

mind filing a bug + referencing it in this comment?

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text: could we move this to the .cc or do implementors require access to private methods inside AudioManager?

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> nit: blank lines between <system includes.h> and "regular chrome includes.h"

Done.

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> we really shouldn't require refcounting but let's save that for another day
> 
> there's some detangling of object lifetimes and cleanup of stream
> creation/deletion that has to happen first before we can tackling that beast
> 
> mind filing a bug + referencing it in this comment?

Will do. crbug seems to be down at the moment so I'll file one tomorrow.

I started out without reference counting (hence all the audio_manager.get()'s that were still in there) but as the cl grew, I saw that lifetime, thread management, shutdown etc were undefined and using scoped_ptr<> + non-ref pointers, all over the place would be risky.  However, the threading model, usage and teardown is a lot more defined now, so switching from refcounted shouldn't be too hard moving forward.

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> could we move this to the .cc or do implementors require access to private
> methods inside AudioManager?

Done.

messages.author: Satish
messages.text: We do this check only for linux because the code to bring up audio settings panel relies on the applications available only in gnome or kde3/kde4 (media/audio/linux/audio_manager_inux.cc). We could either do something fancy like show the link here but start off an IO thread operation to check and hide the link if we can't show the settings UI.. or we can always show this and in the speech input code where we invoke the settings UI show an error dialog if settings UI can't be shown when link was clicked.

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 11:46:19, Satish wrote:
> We do this check only for linux because the code to bring up audio settings
> panel relies on the applications available only in gnome or kde3/kde4
> (media/audio/linux/audio_manager_inux.cc). We could either do something fancy
> like show the link here but start off an IO thread operation to check and hide
> the link if we can't show the settings UI.. or we can always show this and in
> the speech input code where we invoke the settings UI show an error dialog if
> settings UI can't be shown when link was clicked.

OK, thanks for the background.
I'll take care of it in a followup cl.

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text: no ref?

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> no ref?

I went with the flow on this one.  There are already refcounted objects here without a ref, but it's OK for Chrome's implementation, but users have to be aware.
One benefit (well, could actually be a con, see below) of the current approach is that you don't have to #include the full class definition in the cc file and this isn't done for these pointers.  Could it also have something to do with avoiding breaking include rules?  (if that's the case though, then arguably this could be a loophole)

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text:
we should probably re-think this active stream count business at some point

care to TODOify/file a bug for this stuff?

things I'm curious about:
  a) Is it even useful / used?
  b) If so, are all OSes implementing it?
  c) Can we converge on a scheme (i.e., input streams call Increase/DecreaseActiveInputStreamCount() while output streams increment on creation then call ReleaseOutputStream() later on)
  d) Can we make it less error prone (i.e, can the manager handle all of this transparently, perhaps by requiring Stop() to be called on the manager instead of the stream itself)

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text: nit: collapse into {}

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> we should probably re-think this active stream count business at some point
> 
> care to TODOify/file a bug for this stuff?
> 
> things I'm curious about:
>   a) Is it even useful / used?

It's checked against kMaxOutputStreams above.  Other than that, it looks like a debugging aid.

>   b) If so, are all OSes implementing it?

This is the only place I've seen it.

>   c) Can we converge on a scheme (i.e., input streams call
> Increase/DecreaseActiveInputStreamCount() while output streams increment on
> creation then call ReleaseOutputStream() later on)

I think that's a good idea, provided that it is useful :)  I'll ask leandro and satish about usefulness.

>   d) Can we make it less error prone (i.e, can the manager handle all of this
> transparently, perhaps by requiring Stop() to be called on the manager instead
> of the stream itself)

+1 on that.  I'd like to do that on a separate cl if that's alright and with input from the other guys on usefulness etc.

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text:
docs?

also I looked through the patch but couldn't find any callers of this method so OOC when we would we manually call Shutdown() as opposed to deleting the object via refcounts?

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> docs?

Added.

> 
> also I looked through the patch but couldn't find any callers of this method so

AudioManagerLinux calls it although after my changes there, there is less need to do so.

> OOC when we would we manually call Shutdown() as opposed to deleting the object
> via refcounts?

Only in cases where we want to check that we're not leaking something after shutdown or e.g. from tests that verify that the map is empty, thread is not running etc.

messages.author: scherkus
messages.text:
was action_timeout_ms not enough or too much?

would tiny_timeout_ms_ work? (100ms)

perhaps action_timeout_ms() divided by some #?

messages.author: tommi
messages.text:
On 2011/12/09 22:47:30, scherkus wrote:
> was action_timeout_ms not enough or too much?
> 
> would tiny_timeout_ms_ work? (100ms)
> 
> perhaps action_timeout_ms() divided by some #?

action_timeout is 10seconds, which is too long when running all the tests routinely.  I wanted to go with a fixed value since this is an audio file and it's long enough for you to hear a word or two.  A second or even less would do fine too.  I initially used action_timeout_ms() here since tiny was too short and this was the next timeout value in the line.  However, since what we're doing here isn't really an "action" I figured having a constant would make more sense.
I can change it to e.g. action_timeout_ms() / 10 or 5 if you want.
